That deer was not trying to kill anyone, he was just thrashing to get free. I feed deer like that at my house every day. I can touch their antlers and pet them. They look me right in the eyes, wink at me when I wink at them, and wag their tails when I gesture and talk to them in a friendly way. They are very friendly animals and have never been aggressive with me even when I chase some of them much larger than me, sometimes, for being pushy with other deer. If I had my way deer hunting for sport would be banned. Some humane pruning of the population might be appropriate, in certain areas, for various reasons.

I guess that is what they were trying to do with the loppers. The reason the deer got it's head stuck is because these bucks cast their antlers every year once they become brittle, they then grow a new pair of antlers. The deer had an itchy head and wanted to get the antlers off fast so it runs along and slams it's antlers into the ground. I have seen similar things happened to red stags in New Zealand, the deer run along and slam their heads into the ground, or a tree, casting the antlers.
Probably, but sometimes they get the access branches caught on something else so they just try to get it all off

most wont beleive it, but I have found 2 deer wrapped in wire on property next to mine. Always grab a back foot and take down his behind. Tie the 2 back feet with a  slip not. Once he is down loosely wrapped 2 times any rope around front feet but do not tie. The deer thinks he is tied. Cut off the horns or better to cut the wire. Put your knee against his back and untie the back legs. He still thinks his front legs are tied but they are not. Take your knee off his back and stand up, step away.

@guitarzan1283 I am not sure where you are from, but In Ohio, Kentucky and Indiana, There was a time when the population was very low.  "Conservation" efforts then began a campaign of raising deer and releasing them to get the population up.  A majority of "natural" deer today are direct descendants of this artificial population and the courts have recognised this by forcing states to pay insurance companies for this losses resulting from this.

@guitarzan1283  Fact of the matter is all deer are farm raised, animals released, and SOLD by the government.  They are an industry.  In many places they are overpopulated. The system of raising deer on fenced areas for hunting is much more responsible than the state government's ways of free range.
